image.altText: A group of PNG women and babies sitting on a verandah

items.synopsis: A group of bandits that kidnapped an Australian professor in the PNG Highlands appears to have struck again, this time snatching and assaulting a group of women and girls. Warning: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: The PNG gang that kidnapped an Australian professor may now be unleashing new horrors on teen girls

image.altText: Steve Smith hits a straight drive back between the legs of a reaching Josh Tongue

items.synopsis: The stage could not have been more perfectly set for England to back up its post-Edgbaston confidence on day one at Lord's, but the hosts came out flat and the Australians took full advantage, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: Bazball bluster turns to Lord's lethargy as England tackles day one with a lack of energy

image.altText: Protesters and cricketers tangle while orange smoke fills the air

image.altText: Two police officers in front of two police cars

items.synopsis: A court trying to determine the culpability of a WA man over the murder of his parents hears he blames "radionics machines" for telling him to "kill people". WARNING: This story contains distressing content.

title.children: 'I never wanted to kill them': Man accused of double murder says he was 'hearing voices'

image.altText: A woman with dark hair, wearing a rainbow-coloured top, working on her laptop.

title.children: 'They made a huge error': Amber wouldn't have taken on so much debt if she hadn't trusted the RBA

image.altText: Debris from the Titan submersible recovered from the ocean floor.

title.children: 'Presumed' human remains recovered inside debris from imploded Titan submersible as wreck parts returned to shore

image.altText: Vladimir Putin looking contemplatively upwards

items.synopsis: The Wagner mutiny will slowly, over time, corrode the fighting power of the Russian military. And the Ukrainians, who know the Russian military better than anyone on the planet, will be sure to exploit this, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Physical, intellectual and moral: Three ways the Wagner mutiny will impact Russian fighting power

image.altText: The city skyline, with boats on the water in the foreground.

title.children: A stone's throw from Melbourne's CBD, the future of a large parcel of land is the subject of hot debate

image.altText: Pedestrians

items.synopsis: Australia's stock market expected to open fairly flat, with retail trade and job vacancies data for May out this morning providing an update on how much interest rates rises are slowing the economy. Follow the latest live on our markets blog.

title.children: ASX set for flat start, retail trade and job vacancies data out today

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Yesterday, the ASX saw its best-one day rise since April after the Bureau of Statistics said we'd had a surprising decline in monthly inflation. And this morning, the ASX200 futures suggest Australia's share market will open slightly lower, after European stocks made gains overnight but while US stock markets have had a mixed session. Weâ€™ll be getting some important local data from the Bureau of Statistics today at 11.30am: Retail trade (for May) Job vacancies (for May) Australian National Accounts: Finance and Wealth (March quarter) On that last one, household wealth declined by $57 billion in the December quarter 2022, marking the third consecutive quarter of declining wealth - largely due to falling residential property prices. We'll find out today what happened in the March quarter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the ASX open higher?

children.content: Yesterday, the ASX saw its best-one day rise since April after the Bureau of Statistics said we'd had a surprising decline in monthly inflation.
And this morning, the ASX200 futures suggest Australia's share market will open slightly lower, after European stocks made gains overnight but while US stock markets have had a mixed session.
Weâ€™ll be getting some important local data from the Bureau of Statistics today at 11.30am:
Australian National Accounts: Finance and Wealth (March quarter)

On that last one, household wealth declined by $57 billion in the December quarter 2022, marking the third consecutive quarter of declining wealth - largely due to falling residential property prices.
We'll find out today what happened in the March quarter.

image.altText: A composite picture of Veronica Philomena Lockyer and her seven-month-old baby Adell Sherylee Partridge.
